comments.commentBody:
Within our lifetime, Chile, Argentina, Poland, East Germany and many other countries have awakened and emerged from their totalitarian nighmares.

China's nightmare continues to this day.

When it emerges and steps into the sunlight, I will visit, but not before.
...

"I would be strongly in favor of nuclear energy if someone could tell me what would be done with the waste ("spent" fuel) that would render it harmless to man and beast, bush and tree, stream and mountain."

Let me give it a shot. First, you can use reactors that will consume most of the waste that is generated. Once that is done, you can store what is left over in pools of water until most of the highly radioactive material is gone as the short half-life materials decay. What is left over can be encased in small glass spheres and dumped into the very deep ocean where it can do no harm. Keep in mind that gravity will keep the waste well away from human beings and life near the surface. Even if some of the material leaches out into the ocean there will be no difference to the radioactivity levels because anything produced by man will be dwarfed by the amount of radioactive potassium that is naturally found in the ocean and the other radioactive materials brought to the ocean bottom by natural volcanic activity. Waste disposal has never really been a real problem from a scientific or environmental perspective. It has always been a political problem that has been tainted by ideology.

Please continue with Wordplay. I enjoy reading it at 5 A.M. every morning.
It is part of the routine that establishes a mental set for the day.
Very tough.  I suppose I should be impressed by the eight-letter answers, but I'm too worn out by the struggle to care.

I wonder how long this blog will have to be around before some folks get wise to the idea that 538 uses a scientific method for coming to its assessments, and that scientific method does not include partisan screaming or wishful thinking or "based on what I'm seeing."

That said, I'm a little nervous about the House forecast in particular, simply because there are so many districts that haven't been polled at all. In most cases that's because the districts are considered "safe" and the pollsters don't think it's worth the expense. But I wonder how many of those unpolled "safe" districts will generate big surprises on election night.

Could the reason for such uncertainty be solely because of the increase in House districts that have "at least one poll"? The graph that shows the number of races within the single-digits mirrors the graph of the number of polls.

It makes me wonder if this whole analysis is simply because there are more districts being polled this year. If they had polled as many last year, would the same increase in single-digits have shown up? If yes, is this really a new phenomena?

Mike (#19): "Govern against the will of the people, and face their wrath."

Nice sentiment, except that the will of the people is hopelessly confused. I bet you can find majorities for lower taxes, no cuts in Medicare, Social Security, or defense, and by the way deal with the debt. There is no way to do all three, but "the people" will blame "Washington" for not meeting their incompatible demands.

At least health care reform was paid for. Republicans offer no plan for long-term fiscal responsibility, the "Tea Party" even less so (if that's possible). As long as "the people" fail to take responsibility for their government--and their taxes that support the programs they say they want--they'll continue to blame "Washington" instead of themselves.

By the way, Democrats' problems are not due to ignoring "the will of the people." If policies were the cause, then congressional Republicans would be more popular than congressional Democrats, but polls consistently show that's not the case. Does anyone seriously doubt that if the economy was better then Democrats would be doing well too? As always, "it's the economy, stupid!" Democrats don't make the weather, but they're going to get blamed for it. That's how people vote.

Re #2: "Yeah, the old incandescents were probably made in the U.S. at the GE lightbulb plants of which the last one closed forever in September."

Humm... So your argument is that I should be content with an inferior light bulb because it's made in the USA?

I fell for that scam once, back in the '70s, when I was younger and more gullible. Bought a Chevy Vega because it was made in the USA. Worst car I've ever owned.

There's no good reason why American companies can't build good products in this country, be they cars or CFL/LED lights. (After all, the major Japanese automakers manage to build cars here, to Japanese standards.) But unless & until management gets a clue and starts actually doing it, I'm not about to waste money on inferior goods just because they're wrapped in an American flag.

Gene #38 "There is no good news that I know of from an increasing global population. If your religion suggests otherwise, I (and I suspect many others) would be interested to hear and debate the rational. I suspect that beyond invoking God’s directive (Have you ever heard it directly?) there is none.":

Gene, Julian Simon has successfully argued that the contribution of more human brains has always outpaced scarcity. If you have not read his work, I would suggest that you start by Googling "Doomslayer" and read a Wired Magazine article about him that was written about 10 years ago. If you have specific criticisms of his work and have read it, I would be interested in seeing them.

JD

I agree with Girma arguments, which are in line with my publications in this area since 1970’s. The warm and cold phases in temperature follow dry and wet phases in precipitation. Heat-island effect was recorded as back as 1807 in London. In India, in the current decade (2000-2010) the temperature increase was less than 0.06 degrees Celsius which was also the case for the globe. The extreme temperatures recorded during 2002 and 2009 are associated with extreme dry conditions. My studies on solar energy & evaporation also show the impact of dry and wet conditions in a given location (a review of these were given in Solar Energy journal 1987). As per as Revkins observation, emissions control, it is an important issue, as it is a pollution, in terms its impact on health of life forms including soil. Therefore, there is a need to look emission controls in this direction by identifying areas and control measures. World over billions of dollars are being spent for health care as pollution introduced new diseases. For example in agriculture the pollution (air, water, soil, food) and thus health hazards causing chemical input technology to organic input (traditional) technology. In India nearly 50% of production is going as waste due to non-availability of storage facilities and illegal exports by businessmen. The next is fossil fuel sector, some part can be brought down by adopting proper public transport system and secondly certain % of fossil fuel activities could be replaced by solar energy based technology.

Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy, Hyderabad, India

When facing an old warhorse pitcher, just Keep Bunting. . . . .

It is hard to predict how a player will perform, but Conrad was clearly uncomfortable in the position he was playing.  With the post-season on the line, Cox should have taken Conrad out.  He could have put Glaus at 3rd and Infante at 2nd. It is clear that Conrad's three errors cost Atlanta the game.

I'm pleased to see that Mr. Happy Pencil will be greeting us as soon as we have solved the puzzle. I generally know when I have it right, but the confirmation is all to the good. I enjoy the blog for other reasons and expect to continue reading it.

This was a very satisfying Monday puzzle, and I'd like to see more from Mr. Fisher.

Response to Law, who stated "I'm sorry, but any model that says R+18 in a generic congressional ballot just defies common sense. There has never been an election in the history of this country that has shown results even remotely like that. Obviously their screen that takes someone from "registered" to "likely" voter has some issues."

Perhaps you should take a look at the 1894 election, when the Democrats lost 125 House seats out of the 357 total that existed at that time. The extent of that loss wasn't expected either. But then again during that election the economy was in terrible shape and the Democratic president seemed unable to do anything to improve it. If that sounds like the backdrop for the 2010 election, then Gallup could certainly be correct and a loss of 60/70 House seats could easily take place. Even those numbers would still pale in comparison to the 1894 election and even to the 1932 election.

Nate, you make an error of assumption, perhaps a bit of arrogant assumption:
"In total, 407 of the 435 Congressional Districts have a nominee from both parties this year."
Both parties? Last I checked, we had more than two parties.
Smooth call on the Ravens-Broncos game.

Thanks Martin and Tudor - but please don't make me redden, the sun is tough enough here -  I'm happy to notice some faithful names, and  feel connected to this small but bright community.  As for the scofflaw/railleur illustration, it helps to take French for exemple, and i have to agree with you, now that i get a better view on the term. Fact is it makes me redden again .....
However disgusting we find picketing funerals, the first amendment is clear and adding restrictions to this freedom puts us on a slippery, unconstitutional slope.

What did O'Brien's surveys actually report? That universities were moving away from finals altogether? Or, that they were moving away from final exams? It is not clear from the passage above; however, the blog gives the impressions that universities are merely dropping finals. That would be surprising, given that many (if not most) universities require a "final" of some sort.

Similar to the respondent of #13, I never give exams because I do not find them a meaningful learning experience, especially for studying the humanities. But I always assign finals, whether it be papers and/or projects. Perhaps many of my students would prefer a exam. And certainly those would be easier to grade.

For such Passive-Historicists, the 'March of History' argument may be satisfactory enough. But I would ask those P-Hists to think again about the life their children and grandchildren would suffer until History does the right thing.

‘Alice in Wonderland’ become ‘This May Sound Like a Strange Thing to do, but The Time has Come to Investigate Rabbit Holes’.

‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’ becomes ‘Dog Death Afternoon’
Oliver Twist becomes ‘A Gruelling Tale’
'Never Let Me Go' becomes 'Ever Met Me Clone?'
